titleStmt.title: Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Pennsylvania University Museum, E 16264 R

respStmt.resp: Edited by Michael Marx in collaboration with Tobias J. Jocham et. al. TEI version created by Yasmin Faghihi and Huw Jones

availability.p: Image credits: Courtesy of Pennsylvania University Museum Philadelphia .
Image credits: Courtesy of Pennsylvania University Museum Philadelphia.

summary.p: 1 fol. on parchment; Shelfmark: E 16264 R; Qurʾānic Text: Q 11:48-11:51, 11:57-11:60; 7 lines per page; Dimensions: 130 x 107mm (orig. 390 x 340); Script style: kūfī B.Ia; Estimated date of production: 680-750 (?).
The catalogue of Arabic manuscripts kept by the University Museums in Philaldelphia, written by Giorgio Levi Della Vida gives the following information (Levi Della Vida 1981, p. 154.):

"120. Inv. E. 16264 R. 2nd-3rd century A.H./8th-9th century A.D. ? White, thin parchment. 10.7 x 13 cm. Written on both faces. Parts of six lines, and scanty traces of a seventh, written in a brownish ink faded and blurred at various places, appear on the recto and the verso. The fragment is broken on all sides but for a part of the outer margin which is preserved. The size of the original sheet must have been ca. 34 x 39 cm. From the Ellen W. Harrison Collection. Recto: Kor. 11,48 (50) ثم – 51 (54) ويٰقو[م]. Verso: 11,57 (60) ربى – 60 (63) [فـ]ـى. The script is close to the three preceding numbers; however, the vertical shafts are more elongated. The diacritical signs appear as dots or very short strockes [sic!]. No traces of vocalization occur. The verse divider (only on verso line 4, end of verse 58) consists of two slanting strokes."

Script style of this fragment is the early kūfī type B.Ia according to the palaeographical classification of F. Déroche from 1992. The vertical shaft of the letter ʾalif shows the characteristic of leaning to the right as well as the shaft of the letter ṭāʾ/ẓāʾ﻿. The script shows hardly any variations from the script group B.I described by F. Déroche. The final ǧīm/ḥāʾ/ḫāʾ in isolated position has a hook which is round and more pronounced than in the B.I group. The letter ʿayn when isolated shows the same round body of theletter and differs from the same letter in the final position.

The diacritical marks are indicated by small oblique dots. The vocalisation is missing. Mašq is used in the script, which is the elongation of the horizontal components of the script. (Salome Beridze)
